caption_original:
Been asked to dial a 900 telephone number? 

Be wary of unsolicited emails or text messages asking you to call a number to get more information about a service or a promotion.

Typically 900 and 976 numbers are connected to pay-per-call services, which means you’re paying for calls originating from or charged to your telephone, no matter who made the calls or accepted the charges. 

Learn more about avoiding 900 and 976 call fraud: http://ow.ly/9u4F304fULc

If #BackToSchool means new clothes for your kids and donations of what no longer fits to charity, be sure that your donations go to the right place. 

A lot of charities set up donation drop-off bins in convenient locations like shopping mall parking lots, but be sure that the drop-off bin is for a not-for-profit charity organization. #ScamAlert: Computer manufacturers and software companies will NEVER contact you by email to tell you that your computer has been infected with a virus. 

Scammers often pose as “representatives” from reputable IT companies and claim that your computer has been compromised, offering to fix it for a fee. 

Remember: Computer maintenance and virus scanning is not their responsibility—it’s YOURS.

Do you have an “unclaimed balance” sitting in a long-forgotten savings or chequing account? 

An “unclaimed balance” occurs when there is no owner activity on an account for ten years and the owner cannot be reached by the institution. The balance is turned over to the Bank of Canada, which acts as custodian on behalf of the owner.

Learn more about the types of unclaimed balances and find out if the Bank of Canada is holding one with your name on it : http://ow.ly/zlrM3044eVn

If a tree falls on your house, are you covered? 

Answer: It depends. 

Homeowner insurance typically protects against specific perils such as fire or theft, but damage that could have been prevented through proper maintenance typically isn’t covered. That means if the tree is rotting or you failed to prune it as needed, you may be out a whole lot of green. 

A little DIY now can save you unexpected costs in the long run. Learn how to properly prune your trees: http://ow.ly/9frW303WqYS

Do you need to update your relationship status? 

Don’t forget to inform the Canada Revenue Agency soon after you get married, have been separated for over 90 days or have been living with a common-law partner for over a year.

CRA will recalculate your benefits and credits based on your adjusted family net income, the province or territory you live in and the number of children you have and their ages.

Wondering what the letters and numbers next to the individual entries on your credit report mean? 

Lenders use these codes to weigh how well you manage your credit commitments. Letters represent the type of credit you are using. For example, “I” is for installment credit, such as a car loan. Numbers, which range from 1 to 9, show how and when you make your payments. The best number rating you can receive is 1. 

Get the lowdown on credit ratings here: http://ow.ly/wQ5f304hXHi

Many Canadians who are not able to fully manage their finances for a short or a long period of time turn to a power of attorney. A power of attorney is a legal document that gives one or more persons the authority to manage your money and property on your behalf.

caption_original:
Money doesn’t grow on trees! 

Save some green while celebrating National Tree Day: buy an annual Discovery Pass to access over 100 national parks, marine conservation areas and historic sites across Canada. The Discovery Pass can pay for itself in as little as seven days compared to purchasing day passes!

Find out more: http://ow.ly/N8oq304hX9A
